Backdrop CMS Usability Scenario - User Version
Scenarios for Backdrop CMS Usability Evaluation Heavily influenced by 2015 Drupal 8 Usability Study at U of MN Getting Ready: 2 THINK OUT LOUD 2 Context 3 Pre-interview questions 3 SCENARIO 1 - About Page 4 YOUR SCENARIO: 4 YOUR TASKS: 4 EXAMPLE CONTENT: 4 SCENARIO 2 - Venue Page 6 YOUR TASK...

stpaultim Cheers (Karma: 8)
...perhaps add a task of generating a listing (View) of all sessions? ...or too advanced you think?

Not yet. I think I've got at least an hours worth of activity here already. Also - I don't think it's reasonable to expect anyone without any Drupal or Backdrop experience to do anything on views during their first visit.
I think that we could test views with users who have some Drupal experience already. Or maybe we could test a newcomer with views, if we give them some basic information first?

Also - adding a views test would probably require that we generate some content in advance, so test participant doesn't have to enter multiple nodes. This is reasonable to do, but I'm not ready for it yet.
My plan is to run this test on a Tugboat site tomorrow.

...perhaps add a task of generating a listing (View) of all sessions?

To what end? All that's going to show us is that the Views UI isn't user-friendly. Some developers still struggle to understand relationships and contextual filters, let alone the average site-builder. Also, are we in a place where we're willing/able to update the Views UI to make it more user-friendly?
I am very excited. I just ran my first Backdrop CMS UX study. It should be recorded and I hope to upload it tonight. I think that there are some very valuable lessons in it.
Ok, the video is available to anyone on Zoom with this url: (Deleted link, because I'm editing this to provide a better version later)

NOTE: We are learning lessons already. I was sitting next to the volunteer in this case and the volunteer was using his own computer and recording both our voices from his laptop mic. However, it appears to be a directional mic that did it's task very well of picking up his voice, but not mine.

This is not a big problem, because mostly he is talking himself. Occasionally, I interrupt and provide him with some help. Sometimes you can hear me, most of the time you can not. So, often times you can not hear the question, only the answer.

Towards the end, I interrupted him more often and provided clues, because I did not want the test to take more than an hour and so I gave him clues to help him get to the items that we were trying to test.
Another note: We ran this test on a Tuboat demo instance of Backdrop CMS.
I will try to edit this video and add some captions/text to help in places where it's muddled.

The original video was difficult to use, because of the audio problem when I spoke with user. However, I've done a decent job of editing video and adding sub-titles to make the video more useful. I'm in the process of saving and then will try to upload to Youtube. Not sure if I will be able to upload a 61 minute video.
OK, edited version of UX study is available on YouTube at this URL: YouTube - Backdrop Usability Test
It's my intention that this video is public to anyone with URL. I don't think we should publicize this video, but feel free to give link to anyone interested in this project.
This video should not be showing up in search results or in Backdrop CMS channels.
Thanks for doing all this work @StPaulTim++ (the preparation of the script, running the UX study and recording, editing and uploading the video) :+1:

In this test, we tested whether a Wordpress "site builder" was able to figure out and create a custom content type without any instructions or foreknowledge that this option even exists. Is that even a reasonable thing to test?

I am looking for another UX study volunteer. Ideally, (I think) someone with experience building websites with tools other than Backdrop CMS or Drupal. I'm ready to conduct the test via Zoom. Does anyone want to nominate someone?
It's a 60-90 minute commitment.
I watched some of this video (in between consults at work, shhhh) and it is painful to watch!

It was for me, too. I made it about 5 minutes into it before I stopped. I kept wanting to say things like, "Click that link" and "not that one, that one over there." I guess at least now I know I should not be conducting those myself. :slight_smile:

Yes, we had a post-recording discussion about that video, and we seem to agree that many things that are obvious to long-time Drupal/Backdrop people, aren't that obvious for Wordpress people (which is part of the market that we want to reach out to). ...Although most of the WP people will never change to another CMS, there are those that are almost ready to jump to something more advanced ...if their first steps are frustrating, they will give up, and we don't want that. There are tiny things here and there that we can fix/improve.
It's challenging to sit next to someone watching them struggle and not say anything. Of course at some point there is nothing more to learn and you need to help move them along.
For those who found it frustrating to watch, was it also helpful?

If we invest time into more of these studies, and put more innocent volunteers through them, it's nice to know that they are generating some useful data. We can also modify the script to focus on features where we think we can have the most impact.
I'm highly skeptical of doing UX study on anything related to views, because I don't think we're in a position to do anything about it (right now).
But, I think that some commonly used features have high potential for improvement with reasonable investment of effort.

I don't think I got through enough of the video to know if it was helpful. I might try to force myself to watch it again with the idea of seeing how things could be improved, or just to see how and where people struggle.

Just catching up on this thread; thanks for sharing the video, @StPaulTim! I'm listening to the first part and creating a ticket to (someday) watch the whole thing. Especially intrigued by the person talking about their WP experience before diving in to the Backdrop process.
I just did a second UX study. More interesting results.
I look forward to chatting about this today in the meeting, to make sure that this is a good use of time. That we have the bandwidth to process and respond to what we are learning.
That sounds good @StPaulTim
doh... sorry this was noise :/

I've not watched the video(s), so take this with a grain of salt, but I understand they're based on one person performing tasks in Backdrop... Is that really a good way to make decisions about stuff, based on one person's experience? Correct me if I'm wrong

@BWPanda (Peter) - Your correct. We should not make decisions based upon a single users experience. But, we can learn things from one users experience AND we can make decisions based upon a group of UX studies and watching for patterns.
